original_data.question: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for pain in his back. The patient describes the pain as feeling worse in the morning. He says it is a general stiffness that improves when he goes to the gym and lifts weights. He also states that his symptoms seem to improve when he leans forward or when he is cycling. The patient is a current smoker and is sexually active. He admits to having unprotected sex with many different partners this past year. The patient has no significant past medical history and is not currently taking any medications. On physical exam, the patient demonstrates notable kyphosis of the thoracic spine and decreased mobility of the back in all 4 directions. The patient’s strength is 5/5 in his upper and lower extremities. The rest of his physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following findings is associated with this patient’s presentation?

options.A: Diminished pulses in the lower extremity
options.B: Narrowing of the spinal canal when standing upright
options.C: Pain with elevation of his leg while laying down
options.D: Punctate bleeding spots when dermatologic scales are removed

model_response:
The patient’s presentation is most consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects the axial skeleton. It most commonly affects the sacroiliac joints and the spinal column. The patient’s symptoms of pain and stiffness in the back are worse in the morning and improve with physical activity. The kyphotic deformity of the spine is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. The patient’s age, sex, and smoking history are all risk factors for ankylosing spondylitis. The patient’s symptoms of pain with elevation of his leg while laying down is called a positive Gower’s sign and is indicative of extra-articular disease. The other choices are not associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Diminished pulses in the lower extremity would suggest vascular disease. Narrowing of the spinal canal when standing upright would suggest spinal stenosis. Pain with passive range of motion of the hip would suggest hip pathology. Punctate bleeding spots when dermatologic scales are removed would suggest vasculitis.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.

A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Deformities of the SPINE characterized by an exaggerated convexity of the vertebral column. The forward bending of the thoracic region usually is more than 40 degrees. This deformity sometimes is called round back or hunchback.
The vertebrae of the thoracic spine, numbered one through twelve in man.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The distance and direction to which a bone joint can be extended. Range of motion is a function of the condition of the joints, muscles, and connective tissues involved. Joint flexibility can be improved through appropriate MUSCLE STRETCHING EXERCISES.
Degree of intensity or force in regard to a physical activity.
In a place or position that is higher.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.

To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
